quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The PM job can become a little too internal, influencing my stakeholders and getting alignment and all these things. But if you can't sell or support your own product, I don't trust you to build the product.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A contrarian bar for PM effectiveness: credibility comes from being able to sell/support what you build, not just manage internal alignment.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We all talk about product sense. To me, it's just a fancy way of saying you can make good decisions with insufficient data. PMs need as many reps as possible in making decisions, documenting the rationale behind those decisions, and then crucially seeing the outcome of them.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Defines “product sense” as a repeatable decision-making practice and advocates decision logs to learn from outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: When you get to offer stage, I send an email and I say all the terrible things that are probably going to reinforce their fears. If you can tell them that upfront and they can read that whole email and still be equally excited to join you, find yourself a A+ hire.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A concrete hiring tactic (“unsell email”) to stress-test candidate fit and commitment before they join.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We are not even beneath the dust on the surface when it comes to what's going to change.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A memorable perspective-setting statement about how early we are in AI-driven change, encouraging long-term thinking and experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter avatar story and writing online
quotes.text: Oh gosh, probably 2011 or 2012.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A concrete data point showing how long Kevin has kept a consistent online identity via his avatar.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter avatar story and writing online
quotes.text: The story behind that is I was inspired actually by Chris Dixon's avatar at the time and I wanted something really similar to it, but I couldn't figure out how to.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Highlights a practical creative approach: model a strong existing example, then adapt it when execution is unclear.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter avatar story and writing online
quotes.text: Luckily, I was dating a designer at the time, and so she made me that sort of custom pick that has been my profile since then, and she's now my wife.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A memorable story illustrating the leverage of collaborating with skilled partners to create durable personal branding assets.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter avatar story and writing online
quotes.text: Funny enough, I had a startup idea once where it's like a profile picture as a service business where there's these three tiers where it's like one has automated, one has someone illustrates, and one is a professional photo.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A simple product framework (tiered offering) that practitioners can reuse when packaging services from low-touch to high-touch.

quotes.topic_title: Twitter avatar story and writing online
quotes.text: It feels like everyone profile photos are so important.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A pointed observation about the outsized impact of profile photos on online perception and identity.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t start as a PM: build first
quotes.text: The purpose of product management, not the person, but the practice, is to convert that potential into as much realized value for someone as possible, right? Minimum loss.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A memorable mental model framing PM as an energy-conversion function focused on maximizing customer value with minimal waste.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t start as a PM: build first
quotes.text: When you're just getting started with a new product, the people that should be doing that are the people who are building it.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that early product leadership should come from builders closest to execution rather than a dedicated PM.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t start as a PM: build first
quotes.text: That's an engineer, that's a designer, that's a sales person or a support person.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Actionable advice on which roles are best positioned to drive early-stage product decisions and learning loops.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t start as a PM: build first
quotes.text: They're the front line of the smallest loop possible to get something going, and it's through those practices that I think you're able to get the most exposure to what it takes to build a good product.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A practical methodology: optimize for the smallest feedback loop by empowering frontline builders to learn fastest.

quotes.topic_title: Don’t start as a PM: build first
quotes.text: And then from there, that's your foundation. That's the unique perspective that you bring and allows you then to actually take on a "role" of product manager in a good, unique, insightful way.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Advice for aspiring PMs: build foundational experience first so you can later add distinctive value in the PM role.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: First, BuildBetter uses custom models to turn unstructured data like product and sales calls, support tickets, internal communications, and surveys into structured insights. It's like having a dedicated data science team.
quotes.speaker: Unknown
quotes.context: A practical methodology for operationalizing qualitative inputs by converting them into structured, reusable insights.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Second, BuildBetter runs those structured insights into workflows, like weekly reports about customer issues, context-aware PRDs, and user research document with citations.
quotes.speaker: Unknown
quotes.context: Highlights the actionable step of embedding insights directly into recurring product workflows and artifacts.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In a world of AI demos over promising and under delivering, see why BuildBetter has a 93% subscription retention.
quotes.speaker: Unknown
quotes.context: A concrete performance data point that can be used to benchmark real-world product value beyond demos.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Yes, so we just launched OneSchema FileFeeds, which allows you to build an integration with any system in 15 minutes as long as you can export a CSV to an SFTP folder.
quotes.speaker: Christina
quotes.context: A specific, time-bounded approach for rapidly shipping integrations by leveraging a simple constraint (CSV to SFTP).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We have a built-in validation layer that stops any bad data from entering your system, and OneSchema will notify your team immediately of any data that looks incorrect.
quotes.speaker: Christina
quotes.context: An actionable reliability pattern: prevent bad data at the boundary and alert immediately to reduce outages and customer trust loss.

quotes.topic_title: When teams do and don’t need PMs
quotes.text: Good PMs make you better and make your life better, allow you to do the work you want to do and they take all the stuff you don't want to do, make sure the stuff you're doing is worthwhile.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical litmus test for PM value: they increase team leverage by removing unwanted work and ensuring effort maps to impact.

quotes.topic_title: When teams do and don’t need PMs
quotes.text: truly not every team needs a product manager, but the activities, the outcome that one would drive needs to get done no matter what.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Reframes the PM debate from roles to responsibilities: PM work is mandatory even if the PM title isn’t.

quotes.topic_title: When teams do and don’t need PMs
quotes.text: When you are the customer, why the heck do you need someone else to help do the things that let you make decisions on what to build?
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Counterintuitive hiring heuristic: teams building for themselves can often delay PMs because decision-making is inherently closer to the customer.

quotes.topic_title: When teams do and don’t need PMs
quotes.text: SNAP actually is another example where they waited, I think, until they had 200 people before they hired their first PM.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example that some companies scale surprisingly far without PMs because others absorb PM activities until it stops working.

quotes.topic_title: When teams do and don’t need PMs
quotes.text: Someone's doing that, and my feeling is like, "Okay, your designers may love doing that, great. Let them do it." If your engineers that have a lot of product sense may want to do that, great.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable staffing guidance: if non-PMs willingly and effectively cover PM activities, you can postpone hiring a dedicated PM.

quotes.topic_title: Best starting roles: engineering, design, sales
quotes.text: The best way to think about this, in my opinion, is who were the people that you would be taking the PM responsibilities from and then do those jobs?
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A simple framework for choosing a starting role by working backward from the functions PMs typically absorb responsibilities from.

quotes.topic_title: Best starting roles: engineering, design, sales
quotes.text: And so for me, the sort of foundational three are going to be engineer, designer or salesperson.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A concrete shortlist of high-leverage feeder roles that build core PM-adjacent skills.

quotes.topic_title: Best starting roles: engineering, design, sales
quotes.text: In reality, the best salespeople are the best listeners, the best people at understanding the problem that the customer is having and then translating that into what you can do for them.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A contrarian reframe of sales as elite customer discovery and problem translation training for future PMs.

quotes.topic_title: Best starting roles: engineering, design, sales
quotes.text: That could be the conclusion you arrive at, but I think a better way of framing it is, "I'm okay at those things. I'm potentially world-class at this other thing. Let me see what it feels like to double down on this area."
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A mindset shift that positions moving into PM as doubling down on strengths rather than “settling” after not being world-class in another function.

quotes.topic_title: Why great PMs must be great writers
quotes.text: writing is clarity at scale, and a key component to a PM's job is creating clarity both internally and externally, but it is both sides of that that I think often get lost.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A memorable framework for why writing is core to PM work: it scales clarity across both internal alignment and external customer communication.

quotes.topic_title: Why great PMs must be great writers
quotes.text: You should write your PRDs, they should be super crisp, they should articulate things really well, but I'm not saying that every PM needs to be a marketer or a world-class copywriter, but you should be able to write really compelling messaging in the voice of the person that you're trying to serve.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on what “good PM writing” looks like: crisp PRDs plus customer-voice messaging without needing to be a pro copywriter.

quotes.topic_title: Why great PMs must be great writers
quotes.text: if you can't sell or support your own product, I don't trust you to build the product.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A contrarian bar for PM competence that ties product-building credibility directly to the ability to communicate value in writing.

quotes.topic_title: Why great PMs must be great writers
quotes.text: I don't know what I think until I've written it down.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical mental model for using writing as a tool to clarify thinking before trying to align others.

quotes.topic_title: Why great PMs must be great writers
quotes.text: it needs additional revs to be properly consumed by everyone else. And that's I think the really hard part that a lot of folks don't do the extra mile effort to take on.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Highlights an often-missed practice: iterating writing beyond first draft so it’s understandable and usable by the broader team.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a better writer
quotes.text: I explicitly do not mean read a bunch of other PM artifacts. You're not going to become a better writer by reading PRDs or whatever it is or support articles. It needs to be writing that compels.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance to improve writing by studying compelling non-PM writing rather than internal work artifacts.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a better writer
quotes.text: And when I say compels, I mean it pushes you to action. Because if you read something and you're like, "Oh, that's interesting," that's not enough. You need to be able to give someone something that then allows them to do something differently.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Defines a practical bar for effective writing: it should drive action, not just interest.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a better writer
quotes.text: But the more you index towards developing your own taste for what you think is good by consuming others, then you can shift into producing your own and then comparing them and riffing it off other people.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A repeatable improvement loop: consume great writing to build taste, then produce, compare, and iterate.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a better writer
quotes.text: There's this concept of cadence that I think is really important when it comes to internal writing. There's probably some very good article about this, but it's the idea that if you only write in a monotonous cadence, either all really short sentences or all really long sentences, then your brain just tunes out eventually.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Introduces cadence as a concrete technique to keep readers engaged, especially in internal docs.

quotes.topic_title: How to become a better writer
quotes.text: And so you have to interrupt the pattern intentionally, and so you go short-long, long-short, whatever it is, but there's a few various specific things that you can do that allow someone to just roll through a post or something when you write that way.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Actionable tactic: vary sentence length intentionally to prevent reader fatigue and improve flow.

quotes.topic_title: PM-Eng-Design collaboration: constraints and overlap
quotes.text: Most people, I would say, under invest in design, point-blank.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A blunt, contrarian claim that many teams systematically undervalue design resourcing.

quotes.topic_title: PM-Eng-Design collaboration: constraints and overlap
quotes.text: I would rather hire an incremental designer than PM almost any day of the week.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A provocative hiring heuristic that challenges the default instinct to add PMs before designers.

quotes.topic_title: PM-Eng-Design collaboration: constraints and overlap
quotes.text: the best way to get feedback from people is not by asking what they think, but to put something concrete in front of them and then have them react to it, right?
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A practical feedback method: elicit higher-quality input by presenting a tangible artifact to react to.

quotes.topic_title: PM-Eng-Design collaboration: constraints and overlap
quotes.text: PM should be doing everything in their power to draw the perimeter of the space, of the problem space.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A clear role framework for PMs: set constraints/boundaries so the team can explore productively within them.

quotes.topic_title: PM-Eng-Design collaboration: constraints and overlap
quotes.text: But you need these murky overlaps in order to build something really good.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A collaboration philosophy arguing against rigid swim lanes in favor of intentional overlap across PM/Eng/Design.

quotes.topic_title: Square POS story: sweating animation details
quotes.text: This seems like such a small thing, but it made the difference in how easy it was to adopt for a lot of the restaurants.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Highlights that seemingly minor UX details can materially impact product adoption and usability.

quotes.topic_title: Square POS story: sweating animation details
quotes.text: And so a designer and myself spent literally an entire week just fine-tuning how many milliseconds it would take to pop in and out so that it felt right.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A concrete example of investing deeply in interaction details (down to milliseconds) to meet real user needs.

quotes.topic_title: Square POS story: sweating animation details
quotes.text: And we actually brought in servers and bartenders to play with the prototypes we had on iPads and be like, "Here's an order. Pop it in." And we would see where they would sort of flinch or hesitate because the animation was too slow and they thought, "I can't tap it yet," or something related to that.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Demonstrates a practical usability-testing method: observe hesitation points to tune interaction speed for expert users.

quotes.topic_title: Square POS story: sweating animation details
quotes.text: And so it's easy, I think, for a PM to say, "That's not my responsibility. I define the requirements. Have a menu group that goes to the next level, design or engineer, figure it out." No way. That's fully on you, and you better be involved in those details.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Direct advice that PMs should own and engage in critical UX execution details, not just requirements.

quotes.topic_title: Creating time for craft amid deadlines
quotes.text: I definitely don't think it was obvious to everyone, and I can definitely say that because we were given a pretty strict deadline that we needed to launch by and I pushed it out three times.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A concrete example of protecting craft/quality by deliberately moving a deadline multiple times.

quotes.topic_title: Creating time for craft amid deadlines
quotes.text: This is what we believe we need to ship, and this matters much more than hitting some artificial external GA date.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A prioritization principle for choosing customer value and quality over externally-imposed launch dates.

quotes.topic_title: Creating time for craft amid deadlines
quotes.text: All that might be true, but I think there needs to be a calibration or at least a spring-cleaning of, "What's everything I'm doing?" and how much do these things actually matter to getting value to a customer.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Actionable advice to audit your time and cut internally-focused work that doesn’t drive customer value.

quotes.topic_title: Creating time for craft amid deadlines
quotes.text: "Keep the main thing the main thing"
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A memorable mantra for staying focused on the highest-impact work amid competing responsibilities.

quotes.topic_title: Creating time for craft amid deadlines
quotes.text: So I do think you have to take into account what is the DNA of the team. And then can you exploit that? Which I was able to do. Or do you actually have some change management to put into effect if you believe that it's worthwhile?
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A team-level mental model: quality vs. speed “DNA” determines how hard it will be to create space for craft, and whether you should leverage or change it.

quotes.topic_title: Making constraints concrete in PRDs
quotes.text: The best word to describe the perimeter is just constraints. At the end of the day, you should be adding as many constraints as reasonable in order to let engineers and designers come up with the most creative solutions for whatever you're trying to do.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Defines the “perimeter” as constraints and frames constraints as an enabler of creativity for product teams.

quotes.topic_title: Making constraints concrete in PRDs
quotes.text: And so again, if we just stay focused on this point of sale example, one constraint would be, "Who the hell are we serving? Are we trying to go after sit-down restaurants that are serving five different courses and have a 200 item wine list? Or are we trying to serve the taco truck?"
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A concrete example of a high-leverage constraint (customer segment) that dramatically changes solution space.

quotes.topic_title: Making constraints concrete in PRDs
quotes.text: It's just about how do you remove decisions, right? Because this I think is maybe a trite phrase, but the best decision is no decision. If you don't even have to think about the decision, the team is that much more effective.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A counterintuitive principle: reducing decision-making load increases team effectiveness.

quotes.topic_title: Making constraints concrete in PRDs
quotes.text: And so if you say speed is more important than consistency of data, that's a huge tradeoff and constraint that you can give the team." Oh my god, if an engineer hears I don't need real time consistency of data, I can do so much cool stuff and easily accomplish that speed thing."
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Shows how explicitly stating product principles/tradeoffs unlocks technical options and faster delivery.

quotes.topic_title: Tuning fork feedback and silent doc reads
quotes.text: And so even though we hate meetings and we love asynchronous, there is a lot of value to saying, "I need 20 minutes of focused time to interrogate something that I've done. We're not going to talk. I'm literally going to force us into a room or Zoom. You're going to read this doc, I'm going to watch you comment on it in real time. I'm going to respond to your comments in real time. And at the end of this thing I'm going to have enough really good input that I can do a huge rub on this thing and get to the next phase."
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A concrete meeting format (silent doc read + live commenting) that turns feedback into real-time iteration.

quotes.topic_title: Tuning fork feedback and silent doc reads
quotes.text: But that's the best kind then, because it's actual work getting done, right?
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Reframes “another meeting” as productive execution when it’s structured for focused review work.

quotes.topic_title: Tuning fork feedback and silent doc reads
quotes.text: But I don't think we give enough space in any type of meeting for people to actually think. And when you are just staring at a doc with your camera off and the only expectation is to engage with that thing, thoughts are a little bit better and crisper.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Highlights why silent reading can produce higher-quality feedback than discussion-heavy meetings.

quotes.topic_title: Tuning fork feedback and silent doc reads
quotes.text: Although I would urge you to make them come to the meeting.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: A counterintuitive push to prefer synchronous review over promised async feedback to ensure it actually happens.

quotes.topic_title: Tuning fork feedback and silent doc reads
quotes.text: I think this is the part that often gets lost, which is the latency between a comments or question and a quick follow-up from the author just pushes that cycle speed really long in a way that doesn't need to be. And so when people are trying to find how do you move faster, this actually is one of those very good examples of moving slower to move faster.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Explains the core mechanism—reducing feedback-response latency—to speed iteration even if it adds a meeting.

quotes.topic_title: Decision logs to build product sense
quotes.text: To me, it's just a fancy way of saying you can make good decisions with insufficient data, and the core of that is decisions.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Reframes “product sense” into a concrete, trainable skill: decision-making under uncertainty.

quotes.topic_title: Decision logs to build product sense
quotes.text: And so PMs need as many reps as possible in making decisions, documenting the rationale behind those decisions, and then crucially seeing the outcome of them.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Defines the decision-log loop (decide → write rationale → review outcomes) as deliberate practice for PM judgment.

quotes.topic_title: Decision logs to build product sense
quotes.text: There's other companies that are doing crazy things. What are they doing? What would you do if you were responsible for the roadmap? Write it down. A year later, see what they've shipped.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Gives a simple method to generate more “decision reps” by simulating roadmap calls and checking results later.

quotes.topic_title: Decision logs to build product sense
quotes.text: I think decision logs are the lightest weight thing possible. And so you can start super easy by saying, "You know what? Every Sunday morning I'm going to scroll through Twitter, I'm going to check out Hacker News, whatever it is, I'm going to see something interesting and I'm going to make a bet. I'm going to place my decision on this thing." Write it down, and then set a calendar invite in X weeks, X months to see what plays out.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Offers a low-friction habit recipe (10 minutes weekly + calendar reminder) to make decision logging stick.

quotes.topic_title: Decision logs to build product sense
quotes.text: I do want to apply a pretty severe caveat here though, which is, a decision log is not a replacement for building products. It's a additional complimentary thing that you can be doing on your own.
quotes.speaker: Kevin Yien
quotes.context: Prevents a common failure mode: treating armchair predictions as a substitute for hands-on product building.
